cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the main elements of the Italian language. The development of speaking, reading, and writing skills. Introduction to Italian culture and texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Language for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Grade 11 and/or 12 Italian (U or M level) or previous experience or instruction in Italian.

courses.name: Image and Text in Medieval and Renaissance Italian Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will explore various aspect of the interaction between literature and the visual arts in Italy from the Middle Ages to the end of the Renaissance. The focus will be on the intersection between the literary and visual modes of perception in the works of representative Italian authors from the Fourteenth to the Sixteenth Centuries. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Image and Text in Medieval and Renaissance Italian Culture

courses.name: The Fine Art of Murder: Reading Detective Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: Since its inception in the Nineteenth century, detective fiction has been one of the most popular literary genres, proving adept at both entertaining and shining a critical light on social and political problems. This course will explore the many faces of detective fiction addressing questions such as: Why does crime hold such a fascination for modern audiences? What kind of pleasure do we derive from reading stories that often follow established conventions and rules? What do these novels about crime and punishment tell us about broader social and political issues? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Fine Art of Murder: Reading Detective Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of Machiavelli’s political doctrine in The Prince and the development of his ideas in politics, ethics and the arts. Special attention will be paid to the enduring relevance of his legacy in the modern world. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Machiavelli and Machiavellianism

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will explore the role of the Church in the history of Italian culture, including the literary, visual and performative arts. Special attention will be paid to its important functions in different periods of the history of Italy. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Church in Italian Culture

courses.name: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Dante to Tasso

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on authors from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance who had a defining influence on Western literature, such as Dante, Petrarca, Boccaccio, Machiavelli, Ariosto and Tasso. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Dante to Tasso

courses.name: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Marino to Calvino

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on authors from the Baroque to the Twentieth Century who had a defining influence on Western literature, such as Marino, Goldoni, Manzoni, Pirandello, Calvino. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Marino to Calvino

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will explore how notions of identity and (self)-representation emerge in literature by Canadian writers of Italian descent, illustrating the critical evolution of the immigrant journey from its historical experience to its current condition. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian-Canadian Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys the history of Italian cinema and the sociopolitical circumstances surrounding the film industry, from its early days to the present, while also introducing the students to methods of analysis and research appropriate to the field. Emphasis will be placed on films from the silent era to the 1960s, and from the 1960s to the present. This course includes a component designed to introduce students to methods of scholarly research appropriate to the field. The course is given in English and all films shown have English subtitles.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Italian Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Grammar review, readings of Italian authors and oral practice to enhance comprehension and expressive skills.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Italian
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ITA100Y1/ITA151Y1; Grade 11 and/or 12 Italian (U or M level), or previous experience or instruction in Italian, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: Dante: Vita Nuova and Divina Commedia (Inferno)

cmCourseInfo.description: Dante's poetry and great Christian epic of conversion explode with the passions of this world. This course focuses on intertextual and rhetorical strategies used to fashion the author's complex vision of contemporary society within the framework of providential history. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dante: Vita Nuova and Divina Commedia (Inferno)

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of ITA320H1, this course examines the Purgatorio and the Paradiso in the context of Dante's vision of contemporary society. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dante: Divina Commedia (Purgatorio and Paradiso)

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the theme of love in the Renaissance and its development in a variety of literary forms. Analysis of treatises, poetry, short stories and letters with the purpose of examining intertextuality and the practice of imitation, as well as the social and political aspects of love, such as marriage, women's position in society, pornography, homosexuality and other issues. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Love in the Renaissance

cmCourseInfo.description: For students who have completed ITA250Y1/ITA251Y1. Discussion of problems of grammar, style, and composition. Language analysis based on readings of Italian authors. One hour a week of oral practice. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: For students having a knowledge of Italian and/or Italian dialects but no background in linguistics. Concepts of general linguistics. Italy as a linguistic entity. The structure of contemporary Italian, with special regard to its sound system and grammatical categories. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Linguistics

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course that explores specific aspects of Italian Studies. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Subtitle: The Food of the Artist: Literature, Cinema and Painting in the Kitchen, from Dante to the Present Day Course Description: Since food has become so important an aspect of the image of Italy abroad, this course proposes an interdisciplinary exploration of the theme of food in Italian art and culture. Analysis of treatises, poetry, short stories, movies and paintings with the purpose of examining “the language of the food” paying special attention to its social, political, religious and artistical meanings. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course that explores specific aspects of Italian Studies. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Subtitle: The Italian Fantastic Course Description: The course explores various manifestations of the fantastic in literature, and in particular in Italian literature. By considering canonical authors such as Dante, Ariosto and Tasso, together with classics of the Gothic genre and of modern Italian literature (Pirandello, Levi, Calvino), the course seeks to identify the pivotal characteristics of the fantastic as a literary mode. The course considers also the importance of the fantastic in Italian cinema, in authors such as Fellini and Argento. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will study works by the major Italian playwrights of the Twentieth Century, including two of Italy’s Literature Nobel Prize winners, Luigi Pirandello and Dario Fo. Particular attention will be paid to the relationship between individual works and broader literary and cultural movements, as well as to issues regarding staging and production of the plays under discussion. The course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Masterpieces of Modern Drama
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ITA250Y1/ITA251Y1, and at least 0.5 FCE ITA literature courses at the 300-level

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Scripted and Performance Texts in the Commedia dell’Arte Tradition

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on specific topics in Italian Studies, designed for advanced students. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Subtitle: Scripted and Performance Texts in the Commedia dell’Arte Tradition Course Description: This course examines the Commedia dell’Arte in its historical evolution, viewed in the context of the material conditions of performance and in relation to the role of theatre in society subsequent to the creation of the entertainment industry in Renaissance Italy. Among the topics to be discussed in the course are unscripted performance texts, the elements of actor-centred dramatic action, masks, the semiotics of improvisation, the ideology of humour, and minority dramaturgy. We will also consider the hybrid dramatic forms into which Commedia dell’Arte mutated in its last stages of development, including scripted comedy, grotesque dance, pantomime and giullarata. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English) Exclusion: ITA390H1 Prerequisite: Completion of at least 7.0 FCEs

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Editing and Translating Early Modern Italian Texts

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on specific topics in Italian Studies, designed for advanced students. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Subtitle: Working with Pre-Modern Italian Texts: From Transcription to Translation Course Description: This experiential learning course will see students work together in a workshop format to transcribe early modern Italian texts, create a scholarly apparatus for them, and then translate them into English. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. Prerequisite: ITA250Y1/ITA251Y1/ITA252Y1

courses.name: Italian Language and Italian Dialects in Toronto

cmCourseInfo.description: Through an historical overview of Italian immigration in Toronto, the role of Italian and Italian dialects in the city will be examined. As part of the topic studied in course, students will contribute to the website of the OIM by collecting varied forms of empirical linguistic evidence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Language and Italian Dialects in Toronto

cmCourseInfo.description: This advanced-level course is designed to provide students with further study of the Italian language and culture with emphasis on varied methods of expression. This course will improve students' oral and written communication skills.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Italian

cmCourseInfo.description: Opportunity to apply acquired knowledge in a work placement environment. The placement will take place in local community organizations, Private Business Associations and local media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship in Italian
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: Must be enrolled in 4th year._x000D_3.0 CGPA required._x000D_Departmental interview.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For 'E' indicator courses: contact the Undergraduate Coordinator at 416-926-2338 or italian.undergrad@utoronto.ca for an appointment. Departmental Hours: Monday to Friday 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to pursue at the 400-level an independent course of study not otherwise available. A written proposal, co-signed by the instructor, must be submitted on the appropriate proposal form for approval by the Department of Italian Studies. Application deadline: April 30 for F courses, November 30 for S courses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Based on a professor’s research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving concrete training in research. This course is mandatory for all students enrolled in the specialist’s program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Research
